Title: 6 Foods That Make Your Heart Happy
Content:
An overall healthy diet is important to keep your heart working properly. While no one food will offset the negative effects of a poor diet, certain foods are packed with vitamins and nutrients that are especially good for your heart. In fact, if your heart could smile, we think these six foods would do the trick. Learn more about each food below and try out the recipes to add these foods into your diet.

Salmon

This oily fish is rich in omega-3 fatty acid, which is an essential acid that reduces inflammation in your body. It helps make blood less likely to clump and stick to the walls of the arteries and lowers your risk of blood vessel damage. Omega-3 may also lower you triglyceride levels, reduce your risk of stroke and heart disease, and lower the risk of abnormal heart beats, which may lead to sudden death.

Almonds

Almonds are loaded with nutrients such as calcium, magnesium, potassium and protein. They also help maintain good cholesterol levels and can help you raise your HDL (high density lipoprotein) or "good cholesterol" because they are healthy in high polyunsaturated fatty acids. If you don't care for almonds or want to mix it up, you can try hazelnuts, peanuts, pecans, pine nuts, pistachio nuts and walnuts—all have heart health benefits. Just remember to limit your portion to one serving of nuts as they can be high in calories.

Spinach

Spinach is rich in antioxidant vitamins and has anti-inflammatory properties that can help reduce your risk for blood vessel damage and heart disease. It's also high in folate, which has been found to reduce the blood levels of homocysteine, an emerging risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Plus, it's packed with vitamins A, C, and E.

Oatmeal

As a whole grain food, oatmeal provides a heart healthy soluble fiber, which attracts water and turns into gel during digestion. This helps lower bad cholesterol levels because it reduces the absorption of cholesterol into your blood stream. Oatmeal is also low in fat and high in protein, making it a favorite among those who want to manage their weight, blood sugar and diabetes risk.

Beans

Beans are another powerhouse of soluble fiber. They are one of the best foods you can introduce or increase in your diet to protect your heart. Add them to your meals or use them in place of red meat, which is linked to a higher risk of heart disease. Different beans offer different flavors so try a variety (black, navy, white, kidney, or garbanzo) in your diet.

Cacao

The multiple antioxidants and flavonoids in cacao help decrease inflammation, which make it a heart-friendly ingredient. When made into chocolate, the added sugar decreases the health benefits and nutritional value. Stick with dark chocolate that has at least 70% cacao and, if it's too bitter for your taste buds, add it to naturally sweet foods, such as fruit.

Title: Mindful Vegan Poutine
Content:
Traditionally topped with cheese curds and brown gravy, poutine is usually a heavy dish. This Sodexo recipe is a nod to the classic but is both mindful and vegan, using a flavorful vegan demi glace, a faux "cheese" sauce made of carrots and potatoes, and roasted potato wedge fries. So you can enjoy a flavorful dish without feeling heavy when you're done. "I love this plant forward dish; it's a clever take on a popular Canadian tradition," said Senior Executive Chef Hannah Robertson, who makes the dish in the video above. "If you don't want to make the demi glace from scratch, you can buy it online." This mindful version includes carrots and portobello mushrooms for some added nutrition, too. "Portobello mushrooms are a good source of vitamin D, which aids in calcium and phosphorous absorption. These micronutrients play a factor in supporting bone growth," said ProMedica Wellness dietitian Liz Satterthwaite. If you wanted to add in more protein, you could toss in some beans, too. "By including beans, you can also indirectly add more fiber," said Satterthwaite. "Some ideas that can make for a great addition to this meal are pinto beans, kidney beans or black beans." Watch Chef Robertson make this recipe in the video above. Then try making it yourself with the recipe below!

Recipe

[row] [column md="6"] Roasted Greek Fries
  • 1 3/4 pound potatoes
  • 1 tablespoon vegetable oil
  • 1 tablespoon lemon juice
  • 1/2 teaspoon salt
  • 1/2 teaspoon pepper
  • 2 5/8 teaspoon garlic, chopped
  • 2 5/8 teaspoon fresh oregano, chopped
  1. Wash potatoes and dry. Cut each potato into 8 wedges.
  2. Blanch wedges in a steamer for 5-8 minutes or until almost tender and cooked ¾ of the way.
  3. Lightly toss potatoes with vegetable oil, lemon juice, salt, pepper, garlic and oregano
  4. Coat sheet pans with vegetable oil spray. Spread potatoes on sheet pans in a single layer. Do not overcrowd. Bake in a preheated 450 degree oven for 10-15 minutes or until light golden brown.
Vegan "Cheese" Sauce
  • 1 7/8 ounces potatoes, peeled and diced
  • 1 ounce carrots, peeled and sliced
  • ½ teaspoon lemon juice
  • 1 ½ tablespoon water
  • 2 7/8 teaspoons canola oil
  • ¼ teaspoon salt
  • 1/8 teaspoon onion powder
  • 1/8 teaspoon garlic powder
  • 1 1/2 tablespoons nutritional yeast
  • Pinch of cayenne pepper
  1. Boil potato and carrot chunks in water for 15-20 minutes or until tender. Drain.
  2. Place all ingredients in a food processor or blender. Blend until smooth.
[/column] [column md="6"] Vegan Demi Glace
  • 1 ½ teaspoon canola oil
  • 1 oz yellow onions
  • 8 oz water
  • 1 oz demi glace base, gluten free
  • Salt and pepper to taste
OR use 1/2 cup store bought vegan demi glace
  1. Heat oil in saucepan over medium heat until hot.
  2. Add onions and reduce heat to low. Cover and cook for 10-20 minutes or until caramelized.
  3. Add water and demi glace base. Increase heat to medium-low. Stir constantly with a whisk until sauce thickens.
Toppings
  • 1/4 cup Portobello mushrooms, sliced
  1. Spray mushroom caps with vegetable oil spray. Place side down on hot grill to mark. Cook for 3 minutes.
  2. Turn 90 degrees and cook for another 3 minutes to mark caps with crosshatch grill marks.
  3. Flip mushroom cap, side up. Cook for another 5-10 minutes or until moisture has leached out and mushroom is softened and cooked through. Slice into 1-inch strips.
[/column] [/row]

Now put it all together!

  1. Place roasted Greek fries in the center of a serving plate.
  2. Ladle 2 oz demi glace over potatoes.
  3. Evenly top with a few mushrooms, 1 oz "cheese" sauce, seeded and diced tomatoes and thinly sliced green onions

Experts

[row] [column md="3"] Hannah Robertson, Senior Executive Chef [/column] [column md="3"]

Liz Satterthwaite, Dietitian

[/column] [/row]

Title: Strawberry and Grilled Chicken Salad
Content:
Salads are a great way to get some fresh veggies into your diet, but sometimes they can get a little boring. This recipe from Sodexo combines sweet strawberries and savory chicken, and adds crunch with pistachios and pita chip triangles. Don't like pistachios? Walnuts, almonds and pumpkin seeds also offer healthy fat and a bit of crunch. According to ProMedica Wellness dietitian Liz Satterthwaite, this dish is a great "go-to" for protein. "Protein becomes more important the more active you are and as you age," explained Satterthwaite. "Some great vegetarian protein alternatives include cubed tofu, edamame and most legumes with quinoa." Senior Executive Chef Hannah Robertson added, "This is a really pretty salad. If you happen to have basil on hand, try adding in a few torn leaves. It complements the sweet and savory combination of the salad very well." Watch Chef Robertson make this recipe in the video above. Then try making it yourself with the recipe below! [row] [column md="6" sm="6" xs="12"]

Recipe

Ingredients

  • 2 tablespoons olive oil
  • 2 teaspoons white wine vinegar
  • 1 teaspoon honey
  • 1 cup Bibb lettuce, torn
  • 2/3 cup chicken breast, sliced
  • 1/3 cup strawberries, quartered
  • 1/4 cup cucumbers, sliced
  • 2 tablespoons shelled pistachios
  • Pita chips

Instructions

  1. To make dressing, combine olive oil, white wine vinegar and honey in a bowl and stir to combine.
  2. Tear lettuce and place in medium sized bowl. Add dressing and toss to coat.
  3. Place lettuce on serving dish and top with sliced chicken, strawberries, cucumbers, and pistachios.
  4. Serve with pita chip triangles.
[/column] [column md="3" sm="3" xs="12"] [/column] [column md="3" sm="3" xs="12"]

Experts

Hannah Robertson, Senior Executive Chef

Liz Satterthwaite, Dietitian

[/column] [/row]

Title: Southwestern Breakfast Bowl
Content:
This hearty and healthy breakfast bowl is a delicious way to start your day. The Sodexo recipe brings together warm roasted potatoes, a flavorful black bean burger, baked egg whites and colorful fresh pico de gallo. "This dish has so many great, bold flavors; it's a completely satisfying start to your day," said Senior Executive Chef Hannah Robertson, who is seen preparing the dish in the video above. Plus, you don't have to feel the least bit guilty about morning potatoes. "Potatoes are a vegetable," said ProMedica dietitian Liz Satterthwaite. "They provide many benefits and are not the cause of weight gain. They are a great source of energy, are easy to digest and contain vitamin C, A, iron and phosphorus!" Satterthwaite said potatoes are even better when cooked in healthy fats and paired with protein and veggies. So topping this dish with an egg white and fresh pico de gallo is the way to go! There are a few steps to this recipe, but no worries! It's not difficult to make. You can use store bought pico de gallo or even salsa if you're in a pinch. Watch Chef Robertson make this recipe in the video above, then try making it yourself with the recipe below!

Recipe

[row] [column md="6"] Egg
  • 4 egg whites, divided
  • 1/2 teaspoon pepper
  1. Spray two small ramekins with cooking spray.
  2. Place 2 egg whites into each small ramekin and sprinkle each with pepper.
  3. Place pan in a preheated 350° oven for 5 minutes.
  4. Remove each egg with a rubber spatula.
Roasted Potatoes
  • 1/2 cup potatoes, cubed
  • 1 teaspoon garlic, minced
  • 1/4 teaspoon chili powder
  • 1/2 teaspoon cumin
  • 1/8 teaspoon pepper
  • 1/4 teaspoon salt
  • 1 teaspoon olive oil
  1. Boil cubed potatoes until slightly softened, about 5 minutes.
  2. Heat olive oil in a saute pan. Add garlic and saute for 30 seconds or until fragrant.
  3. Add potatoes, chili powder, cumin, pepper, and salt. Toss evenly to coat. Saute for 2 to 3 minutes.
  4. Spray sheet pan with cooking spray and place potatoes on pan in a single layer. Roast in preheated 400° oven for 15 to 20 minutes or until tender and golden, turning halfway through.
[/column] [column md="6"] Black Bean Burger Crumble
  • 1 teaspoon olive oil
  • 1/4 cup green pepper, diced
  • 1/4 cup black bean burger, cooked as directed, chopped
  1. Heat olive oil in a saute pan. Add diced green peppers and saute until slightly tender.
  2. Add chopped black bean burger, cooked as directed. Saute 5 to 7 minutes.
Pico de Gallo
  • 3/4 cup tomatoes, diced
  • 1/3 cup red onion, diced
  • 1/4 cup green peppers, diced
  • 2 tablespoons jalapenos, diced
  • 3 tablespoons cilantro, chopped
  • 1/8 teaspoon black pepper
  • 1/8 teaspoon salt
  • 3 teaspoons lime juice
  1. Combine tomatoes, onions, green peppers, jalapenos and cilantro in a bowl. (Be sure to wear gloves when handling the jalapenos). Season with salt and pepper. Toss evenly in lime juice.
[/column] [/row]

Now put it all together!

Combine roasted potatoes and black bean burger crumble in serving dish. Top with the baked egg white and sprinkle with fresh pico de gallo. Garnish with a sliced radish (optional). Serves 2.

Experts

[row] [column md="3"] Hannah Robertson, Senior Executive Chef [/column] [column md="3"]

Liz Satterthwaite, Dietitian

[/column] [/row]

Title: Mango Pineapple Smoothie Bowl
Content:
Need a quick, delicious way to get vitamins and minerals? This smoothie bowl recipe from Sodexo brings together the nutritional powers of quinoa, mango, and pineapple, and sweetens it up with a touch of almond milk and coconut flakes. "Quinoa is a great nutrient-packed food to incorporate in your diet and is considered a grain," explained ProMedica dietitian Liz Satterthwaite. "It also contains a healthy dose of fatty acids. About 25% of quinoa is fatty acids, which make it heart healthy." The fruit in the smoothie offer nutritional benefits, too. "Mango and pineapple are a great source of fiber, vitamin C, vitamin A and manganese," said Satterthwaite. Senior Executive Chef Hannah Robertson agreed it's a beautiful and nutritious start to your morning. "I love this smoothie bowl; it's so clever," she said. "Adding the quinoa to a smoothie provides protein, amino acids and is an excellent source of fiber and iron, not to mention it helps with sustained energy throughout your day and is a good gluten free option." Watch Chef Robertson make this recipe in the video above. Then try making it yourself with the recipe below! [row] [column md="6"]

Recipe

Ingredients

  • 1/4 cup cold, cooked quinoa, prepared as directed
  • 1/3 cup frozen banana
  • 1/3 cup frozen mango
  • 1/3 cup frozen pineapple
  • 5/8 cup almond milk
  • 2 tablespoons granola
  • 1/3 cup fresh mango chunks
  • 1/3 cup fresh pineapple, diced
  • 1/2 tablespoon coconut flakes

Instructions

  1. Place quinoa, frozen banana, frozen mango, frozen pineapple and almond milk into blender and blend until smooth.
  2. Pour blended smoothie into a serving bowl. Top evenly with fresh mango, fresh pineapple, granola and coconut flakes.
  3. Serve while cold and enjoy!
[/column] [column md="3"] [/column] [column md="3"]

Experts

Hannah Robertson, Senior Executive Chef

Liz Satterthwaite, Dietitian

[/column] [/row]

Title: Easy, Healthy Butternut Squash Soup
Content:
When the weather gets chilly, butternut squash soup is a quick and healthy meal for the family. It’s a great source of beta carotene, fiber and it’s easy to make, all in one pot. If you're not familiar with butternut squash, it's a dense squash that can be a little tricky to chop. Start by cutting off the top and bottom of the butternut squash, then cut it in half horizontally. Peel the top and bottom pieces separately and remove the seeds before cutting the squash into cubes.

Download the Butternut Squash Soup Recipe

Ingredients

  • 1 tablespoon olive oil
  • 1 medium-large onion, chopped
  • 2 pounds butternut squash, peeled and chopped
  • 1 large carrot, chopped
  • 3 sprigs fresh rosemary
  • 4 cups low-sodium chicken or vegetable stock
  • 3 bay leaves
  • 1 cup skim milk powder

Directions

  1. In a large skillet over low heat, saute the onion in olive oil for 3-4 minutes, careful not to caramelize the onions.
  2. Add carrot and squash to saute pan and mix with the onions. Place rosemary sprigs on top and add the chicken broth. Then add the bay leaves. Cover the skillet and let the mixture simmer for 12-15 minutes or until the vegetables are tender.
  3. Remove the rosemary sprigs and the bay leaves. Add the skim milk powder and stir into the mixture.
  4. Use a hand blender to puree the mixture until smooth.

Title: Grilled Lemon-Sage Chicken
Content:
Get the grill ready for this flavorful chicken recipe! Let the chicken marinade for a quick half hour or for a few hours while you're away for a fresh lemon sage flavor. Then cook on the grill for an entrée that's ready in less than 10 minutes! Download and print the recipe or view below.

Grilled Lemon Sage Chicken

Ingredients
  • 6 boneless, skinless chicken breast halves (about 4oz each)
  • 6 lemon slices, cut in half (optional)
  • Fresh sage leaves (optional)
Marinade
  • 1 teaspoon olive oil
  • 1 teaspoon grated lemon zest
  • 1/4 cup fresh lemon juice
  • 1/4 cup chopped fresh sage leaves
  • 1 tablespoon chopped fresh rosemary or 1 teaspoon dried, crushed
  • 2 or 3 medium garlic cloves, minced
  • 1 teaspoon black peppercorns
  • cracked 1/2 teaspoon salt
Directions
  1. In a large resealable plastic bag, combine the marinade ingredients.
  2. Discard all the visible fat from the chicken. Put the chicken with the smooth side up between two sheets of plastic wrap. Using a tortilla press, the smooth side of a meat mallet or a rolling pin, lightly flatten the chicken to a thickness of ¼ inch, being careful not to tear the meat.
  3. Add to the marinade. Seal the bag and turn to coat. Refrigerate for 30 minutes to eight hours, turning occasionally. Discard the marinade.
  4. Preheat the grill on medium-high.
  5. Grill the chicken for 6 to 7 minutes on each side, or until no longer pink in the center.
  6. To serve, garnish with the lemon slices and sage leaves.
Nutrition Info: Makes 6 servings. Per serving: 125 calories, 1.5g total fat, 66mg cholesterol, 268mg sodium, 0g carbohydrates, 0g fiber, 0g sugar, 26g protein

Title: Fruit and Spinach Smoothie
Content:
My husband and I started making fruit smoothies for breakfast when I noticed that we weren’t getting in enough fruit throughout the day. This recipe is one that I developed and love to share because of its delicious flavor and balanced nutrition. Plain Greek yogurt is my favorite addition to smoothies. The Greek yogurt adds a boost of protein to the smoothie, and the fact that it’s plain yogurt means it is lower in sugar than flavored varieties. The plain yogurt gives a creamy texture to the smoothie and lets the natural sweetness of the fruit shine! Make sure to look for yogurt that has added vitamin D, since many of us are low in this important nutrient. Smoothies also offer a good opportunity to sneak in some vegetables, such as the spinach included in this recipe. You can try out variations of this recipe by mixing in different vegetables and swapping in other fruits to find your favorite combination.
Download the Fruit and Spinach Smoothie recipe.
Fruit smoothies make for a fun and delicious treat; whip one up as a snack or enjoy as part of a healthy meal! Chloe Plummer, MS, RD, LD, is a clinical dietitian with ProMedica Advocacy and Community Health, and her main passion is promoting childhood and adolescent health and wellness. She has a bachelor of science degree in Health and Sport Studies from Miami University and a master of science degree in Clinical Nutrition from Rush University. Title: Tandoori Shrimp on the Grill
Content:
Tandoori is an Indian method of cooking meat or vegetables in a cylindrical clay oven called a tandoor. With this particular recipe, a grill can be substituted to act as a tandoor. Shrimp is a lean protein that is a good source of heart healthy omega-3 fatty acids as well as vitamin B12. This recipe is low in fat (7g) and calories (172). Plus, the combination of spices adds flavor without increasing the sodium, making it a healthy option for those with diabetes, heart disease or high blood pressure. And, the simplicity of this recipe means it's tasty, healthy and fairly effortless.

Title: 3 Meals for Meatless Mondays
Content:
With food prices (especially meats) at a seemingly all-time high, more people are taking the plunge into “Meatless Mondays” or another version of meatless meals at least once per week. Perhaps it isn’t to save some moolah, but rather to lower your intake of saturated fat and increase your intake of vegetables and fiber. Or maybe you have a really picky eater who won’t touch meat and are concerned with making sure they are getting in enough protein. If any of these scenarios are true for you then these three meatless recipes are right up your alley: Family friendly, high protein, healthy, and not too scary. Enjoy!

Black Bean Quesadillas

Loaded with butternut squash, spinach, black beans and cheese, and wrapped in a whole wheat tortilla, these quesadillas are fun and flavorful. Download the Black Bean Quesadilla recipe. Or try this version from my colleague, ProMedica Wellness dietitian, Nathan Drendel. He uses sweet potato in place of butternut squash and jazzes it up with salsa.

Veggie Nuggets

This veggie-packed finger food is perfect for kids. It's a great way to sneak in carrots and broccoli, too. Download the Veggie Nuggets recipe.

Cauliflower Crusted Pizza

Start with a cauliflower crust and top with a Greek yogurt pesto and some veggies for a fun, meatless meal. Download the Cauliflower Pizza Crust recipe and the Greek Yogurt Pesto and Veggie Pizza recipe. Click here for more healthy recipes to inspire your meals! Kinsy McNamee, MS, RD, LD, is a registered dietitian at ProMedica Wellness. Read more of her stories from her monthly Eating Right In Real Life series.

Title: Vegetable Egg Casserole for Mother's Day
Content: Making a nice breakfast for Mom doesn't have to be complicated. Here's a simple egg casserole created by ProMedica Wellness dietitian Nathan Drendel that's packed with vegetables, bacon and cheese that you can make in a slow cooker. With just a little patience, you'll have a delicious, protein-rich breakfast to start the day. View the video below to see how easy it is to make and download the recipe here. Visit our Recipes section for more delicious eats!

Title: Kid-Friendly Fruit Pizza
Content: Cooking with your child is a fun way to teach food basics and healthy eating habits. That's why Hannah Robertson, senior executive chef at ProMedica Toledo Hospital, visited Children's Discovery Center for a "Kids in the Kitchen" healthy eating demonstration. Preschoolers age 4-5 donned aprons and chefs hats and rolled up their sleeves to make mini fruit pizzas. These fruit pizzas, topped with yogurt and fruit, are easy to make and fun for all ages. Download the Fruit Pizza Recipe here and make it with your little one!
